titlestmt.titleproper: Smith-Houston-Ogden family papers. A. Lewis Smith papers (series 59) 1720-1915 1830s-1890s
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection-level EAD record is a product of the Philadelphia Area Consortium of Special Collections Libraries (PACSCL) Consortial Survey Initiative, which was funded by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: Machine-readable finding aid generated in EAD from data in the PACSCL Consortial Survey Database on 12/21/2012

did.unittitle: Smith-Houston-Ogden family papers. A. Lewis Smith papers (series 59)

bioghist.p: Abraham Lewis Smith (1831-1913), a respected and much admired lawyer, was born to Dr. George Smith (1804-1882) and Mary Lewis (1808-1892) in Upper Darby Township, Delaware County, Pennsylvania in 1831. Smith graduated from the University of Pennsylvania with a Bachelor of Arts degree in 1850, and a M.A. and Bachelor of Laws in 1853. In 1859, A. Lewis Smith married Rebecca Levis Wood (1837-1925). Together the Smiths raised four children: Henry Clement (1860-1936), Rebecca (1862-1947), Lewis Lawrence (1864-1931) , and Helen Bright (1875-1958). A. Lewis Smith was active in a number of community businesses and organizations; he was director of the Media Title and Trust Company, director of the West End Trust Company, Secretary of the West Chester and Philadelphia Railroad; President of the Delaware County Historical Society; a longtime advisor to the administration of the University of Pennsylvania, and a Vice President of the Alumni Society. He was also a member of the Historical Society of Pennsylvania, Swedish Colonial Society, Genealogical Society, Delaware County Institute of Science, and Pennsylvania Society of the Sons of the American Revolution. Smith also served as a Media Borough councilman representing the West Ward.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of the papers of A. Lewis Smith. Materials include: grade school and college notebooks and grade reports; account books, stock certificates, and receipts; letters to Smith from family members; legal documents, including property deeds, for legal cases in which Smith was involved as an attorney or executor; printed material including "paper books" of counsel in legal cases; a few blueprints detailing proposed property development in Media, Pennsylvania; and correspondence, newsletters, and applications relating to A. Lewis Smith's membership in the Philadelphia Lawyer's Club, Sons of the American Revolution, and the Delaware County Historical Society among others.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
